explanation:
Include the implementations of these symbols because they are invoked directly (or transitively) from lfs_ctz_find and any for-loops inside them (or inside functions they call) must be checked for MISRA well-formedness. Short reasons:

- lfs_ctz_index: called at function start; its body may contain for-loops or call other functions that do. We must inspect its loops and any effect they have on objects visible to callers.
- lfs_popc: callee of lfs_ctz_index. Its implementation may contain for-loops (or other control structures) whose well-formedness must be checked.
- lfs_min: used to compute skip (in loop body) and is also called transitively by lfs_bd_read. If lfs_min is a macro or function with side-effects or loops, those must be examined because they execute inside the while-loop body.
- lfs_npw2: used in computing skip. Its implementation may contain loops (e.g. bit loops) that must be verified for MISRA for-loop rules.
- lfs_ctz: called when computing skip. Its implementation may contain loops that must be checked.
- lfs_bd_read: called inside the while-loop body and passed &head (i.e. it writes into a local variable). Any for-loop inside lfs_bd_read (or functions it calls) contributes to the behaviour of the while-loop body and therefore must be validated for well-formedness and side-effects.
- lfs_aligndown / lfs_alignup: callers of lfs_bd_read (per the static graph). Their implementations must be checked for internal for-loops and side-effects.
- lfs_fromle32: called immediately after lfs_bd_read; include to ensure it contains no for-loops or side-effects that would affect analysis.

Note: The target function itself contains no for-loop; the MISRA rule applies to for-loops anywhere that contribute behaviour to the function (including functions called from inside the while-loop). The listed symbols are the minimal set (callees and their immediate callees from the static call graph) required to inspect for any for-loops and to determine compliance.
